text:
Tuesday, Feb 21, 2017 8:14 PM UTC Richard Spencer attempted to crash a Libertarian conference and was shown the door Libertarians emphasize private property rights, so crashing their private event was not the smartest idea Topics: Libertarian Party , Libertarianism , Richard Spencer , Life News , News , Politics News (Credit: Courtesy National Policy Institute) 
Richard Spencer â€” the alt right leader who vowed â€œweâ€™re not going awayâ€ after Donald Trump won the presidency, was caught leading a Nazi salute for Trump and who got punched in the face at his heroâ€™s inauguration â€” was evicted from the 10th annual International Students for Liberty Conference after trying to crash its party. 
â€œSpencer, a self-declared white nationalist who believes the U.S. is losing its white identity, had no business attending a gathering of libertarian students, and conference organizers had every right to eject him,â€ Robby Soave wrote in Reason Magazine . â€œIndeed, their decision to do so was a valid exercise of libertarian principles in action.â€ 
Soave described how Spencer â€œset himself up in the bar of the hotelâ€ in Washington D.C. where the event was being held and â€œattempted to host an unscheduled and unwanted conversation about his despicable views.â€ He was eventually confronted by libertarian pundit Jeffrey Tucker, who â€œconfronted Spencer and made clear to the alt-right provocateur that he â€˜did not belongâ€™ at ISFLC. Some shouting ensued, and hotel staff intervened. Shortly thereafter, Spencer left.â€ 
In characteristic libertarian fashion, Soave pointed out that â€œthe Marriott Wardman hotel is private property, and should enjoy the absolute right to evict irksome and unwelcome guests from its premises.â€ 
Spencer has naturally availed himself of the opportunity to troll libertarians on his Twitter account.
